critique: This executive order expands the authority of the Office of Defense Transportation to include all domestic transportation within US territories and possessions. During World War II, this would have been used to coordinate resources and logistics. There is no direct indication of ideological tilt. The order does not directly address immigration. The order expands executive power by broadening the scope of an existing office. The order centralizes control over transportation at the federal level. The order likely prioritizes national security by ensuring efficient transportation of resources. The order involves government intervention in the economy by controlling transportation. The order does not directly address social inclusion.
